citations.narrative:
The facility is not maintaining adequate records of acquisition and disposition. Cage cards are used for acquisition records
for litters of puppies; however, they do not contain all of the required information such as: USDA license number,
individual puppy identification numbers, gender of each puppy, color, breed, and date of disposition as required by the
Animal Welfare Act Regulations subpart 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix).
Additionally, not all of the APHIS 7006 Record of Disposition forms evaluated during the inspection are being filled out
completely. Approximately 15 forms from 2023 and 2024 were missing required information found in the Regulations
under 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix), such as the date of disposition, the name and address of the person who purchased the dog and
whether or not that person is licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and State and the driver’s license
number of the person who purchased the dog, method of transportation, and the method of disposition (sale, donation,
etc).
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out
of the facility, especially in cases of loss or theft. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records for forms which fully
and correctly disclose the information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is
transported, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while
in his or her control. Correct by maintaining complete records for acquisition and disposition by December 25, 2024.

The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations in adult dogs. The Animal Welfare Act
(AWA) requires vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus.
The facility’s PVC prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be given according to label directions, and for the distemper and
parvovirus vaccines to be given yearly to adult dogs. None of the adult dogs at the facility are up to date on all three of the
vaccines required by the AWA, nor do they have a prior history of vaccines.
Failure to follow the PVC for vaccinations leaves the dogs susceptible to diseases, which, if contracted, would cause pain,
distress, and suffering. It is also important for breeding dogs to be vaccinated because they will pass immunity from
vaccines onto their offspring. Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper,
parvovirus, and rabies) in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer
recommendations. Correct By: January 15, 2025, onward.

The facility has not retained copies of all medical records. The facility reports yearly fecal testing was completed during
the kennel inspection by the Attending Veterinarian, with the most recent being completed on 4/24/24. However, the
facility does not have a copy of the results for any of the fecal samples. Maintaining medical records assists APHIS
inspectors in confirming adequate veterinary care is being provided to the regulated dogs at the facility. Dealers must
keep copies of medical records for dogs, including the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other
required or recommended test or examination. Correct by: December 25, 2024, onward.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility is not maintaining adequate records of acquisition and disposition. Cage cards are used for acquisition records 
for litters of puppies; however, they do not contain all of the required information such as: USDA license number, 
individual puppy identification numbers, gender of each puppy, color, breed, and date of disposition as required by the 
Animal Welfare Act Regulations subpart 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix).  
 
Additionally, not all of the APHIS 7006 Record of Disposition forms evaluated during the inspection are being filled out 
completely. Approximately 15 forms from 2023 and 2024 were missing required information found in the Regulations 
under 2.75(a)(1)(i-ix), such as the date of disposition, the name and address of the person who purchased the dog and 
whether or not that person is licensed under the Act, the vehicle license number and State and the driver’s license 
number of the person who purchased the dog, method of transportation, and the method of disposition (sale, donation, 
etc).  
 
Accurate record keeping is essential so that APHIS inspectors can adequately identify the movement of dogs into and out 
of the facility, especially in cases of loss or theft. Each dealer shall make, keep, and maintain records for forms which fully 
and correctly disclose the information concerning each dog purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, or which is 
transported, sold, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer. The records shall include any offspring born to any animal while 
in his or her control. Correct by maintaining complete records for acquisition and disposition by December 25, 2024. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following the Program of Vet Care (PVC) for vaccinations in adult dogs. The Animal Welfare Act 
(AWA) requires vaccinations for contagious and/or deadly diseases of dogs, including rabies, distemper, and parvovirus. 
The facility’s PVC prescribes for the rabies vaccine to be given according to label directions, and for the distemper and 
parvovirus vaccines to be given yearly to adult dogs. None of the adult dogs at the facility are up to date on all three of the 
vaccines required by the AWA, nor do they have a prior history of vaccines.  
 
Failure to follow the PVC for vaccinations leaves the dogs susceptible to diseases, which, if contracted, would cause pain, 
distress, and suffering. It is also important for breeding dogs to be vaccinated because they will pass immunity from

vaccines onto their offspring. Correct by administering all of the vaccines required by the Animal Welfare Act (distemper, 
parvovirus, and rabies) in accordance with a schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and vaccine manufacturer 
recommendations. Correct By: January 15, 2025, onward. 
3.13(b)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility has not retained copies of all medical records. The facility reports yearly fecal testing was completed during 
the kennel inspection by the Attending Veterinarian, with the most recent being completed on 4/24/24. However, the 
facility does not have a copy of the results for any of the fecal samples. Maintaining medical records assists APHIS 
inspectors in confirming adequate veterinary care is being provided to the regulated dogs at the facility. Dealers must 
keep copies of medical records for dogs, including the dates and findings/results of all screening, routine, or other 
required or recommended test or examination. Correct by: December 25, 2024, onward. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
